questions.text: Which of the following is a typical organism causing infective endocarditis based on 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A) Enterococcus faecalis

Explanation:

 

2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria for infective endocarditis (IE) - Typical and Non-typical Organisms

Typical

Non-Typical

For General cases:

  • Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus lugdunensis
  • Enterococcus faecalis (Option A)
  • All streptococci (except Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus pyogenes)
  • Granulicatella, Abiotrophia, Gemella species
  • HACEK group (e.g., Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella)

 

For cases involving intracardiac prosthetic material, additional typical organisms include:

  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci
  • Corynebacterium striatum, Corynebacterium jeikeium
  • Serratia marcescens, Cutibacterium acnes
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C ruled out)
  • Non-tuberculous mycobacteria (e.g., Mycobacterium chimaera)
  • Candida species

Organisms classified as non-typical are less frequently associated with IE and require three or more positive blood cultures for diagnosis.

 

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option B ruled out)
  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D ruled out)
  • Non-faecalis enterococci

questions.text: A 78 year old man, three months after undergoing transcatheter aortic valve replacement presents with high grade fever with chills and rigors. What is the most common causative organism in TAVR-associated infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Solutions : option B ) Enterococcus spp

 

Enterococcus spp. is the most common causative organism associated with TAVR-related infective endocarditis followed by S. Aureus.

Option A is for community acquired native valve -IE.

For C.I.E.D ( Cardiac implantable electronic devices like pacemaker), infective endocarditis leading organism is C.O.N.S > Staph. Aureus

questions.text: Which of the following is a minor criterion for diagnosing infective endocarditis based on 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria?

choices.text: PCR from a sterile body site identifying a typical pathogen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PCR from a sterile body site identifying a typical pathogen

Explanation:

  • Positive Blood culture is a major criteria and option D ruled out.
  • Echo showing valve perforation is a major criteria, so option B is ruled out
  • Negative blood culture would not be considered for diagnosis so option A is ruled out.
  • PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing of typical pathogens from sterile sites other than cardiac tissue is now a minor criterion.

The 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis - Minor Criteria Updates

Predisposing Conditions

Expanded to include transcatheter valve procedures, endovascular leads of cardiac implantable devices, and a history of IE.

Vascular Phenomenon

Includes splenic and cerebral abscesses.

Immunological Phenomena

 Clarifies immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, with a practical definition involving unexplained acute kidney injury, hematuria, proteinuria, or a renal biopsy showing immune complex disease.

Microbiological Evidence

 PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing of typical pathogens from sterile sites other than cardiac tissue is now a minor criterion

Imaging

 Abnormal metabolic activity detected by [18F]FDG PET/CT within three months of prosthetic valve or device implantation is included.

Physical Exam

 A new regurgitant murmur on auscultation is considered a minor criterion when echocardiography is unavailable.

questions.text: A 70 year old man with a prosthetic aortic valve has a fever, positive blood cultures for Enterococcus faecalis, valve vegetations visualized on echocardiography. Cardiac Computed Tomography shows a valve abscess. Which finding is a new major criterion for infective endocarditis in the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria?

choices.text: Direct visual evidence of vegetations during surgery
Positive blood cultures with Enterococcus faecalis
Development of a new onset murmur

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Direct visual evidence of vegetations during surgery

Explanation:

Findings like valvular vegetation, perforation, aneurysm, intracardiac fistula or abscesses on CCT are now considered major criteria according to the updated 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis.

The 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis - Major Criteria Updates

Microbiological Criteria

Expanded "Typical" Pathogens:

The list now includes Staphylococcus lugdunensis, Enterococcus faecalis, and other streptococci, excluding S. pneumoniae and S. pyogenes.

Additionally, Granulicatella, Abiotrophia, and Gemella species are now recognised as typical IE pathogens.

Prosthetic Material-Associated Pathogens:

In intracardiac prosthetic devices, certain bacteria like coagulase-negative staphylococci and Corynebacterium species, as well as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, are considered typical.

Simplified Blood Culture Protocol:

Timing and separate venipuncture rules have been removed, though separate draws are still ideal.

Fastidious Pathogens:

New criteria account for hard-to-culture organisms like Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella, and Tropheryma whipplei, diagnosed via PCR or specific serology.

Imaging Criteria

Cardiac CT (CCT):

Findings like valvular vegetation, perforation, aneurysm, intracardiac fistula or abscesses on CCT are now considered major criteria. (Option A)

 

[18F]FDG PET/CT:

Abnormal metabolic activity on [18F]FDG PET/CT, especially around prosthetic valves or intracardiac devices, is recognised as a major diagnostic criterion.

Surgical Evidence

Intraoperative Findings:

Direct visual evidence of IE during surgery, such as vegetations or abscesses, qualifies as a major criterion in cases without other definitive findings.

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents to the dental clinic for a tooth extraction. He has a prosthetic heart valve placed two years ago and reports a penicillin allergy.Which of the following prophylactic antibiotic regimens should be administered to this patient before his dental procedure to prevent infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Amoxicillin 2g orally 1 hour before the procedure
Ampicillin 2g IV or IM within 1 hour before the procedure
Clarithromycin 500 mg orally 1 hour before the procedure
Cefazolin 1g IV or IM 30 minutes before the procedure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clarithromycin 500 mg orally 1 hour before the procedure

 

Explanation:

Clarithromycin is a suitable alternative for patients with penicillin allergies and is indicated for prophylaxis in patients with prosthetic heart valves.

 

High-risk cardiac Lesions for endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedures

Prophylactic Antibiotic Regimens for endocarditis in adults with high-risk cardiac lesions
  • Prosthetic heart valves or material
  • Left ventricular assist devices or implantable cardiac defibrillator.
  • Prior endocarditis.
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits.
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair.
  • Repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to the prosthetic material.
  • Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement
  • Valvulopathy developed after cardiac transplantation.

Standard oral regimen

(Option A ruled out)

Amoxicillin: 2g oral 1hr before procedure

Inability to take oral medication

(Option B ruled out)

Ampicillin: 2g IV or IM within 1hr before procedure

Penicillin allergy

  1. Clarithromycin or Azithromycin: 500 mg PO 1hr before procedure.
  2. Cephalexin: 2g oral 1hr before procedure.
  3. Doxycycline: 100 mg oral 1hr before procedure.

Penicillin allergy, inability to take oral medication (Option D ruled out)

Cefazolin or Ceftriaxone: 1g IV or IM 30 mins before the procedure.

questions.text: A 55 year old man with a history of prosthetic valve deployment presents with fever, chills, and fatigue. Blood cultures reveal methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The patient has a prosthetic valve and shows evidence of vegetation on echocardiography. What is the appropriate antibiotic regimen for managing this patient’s infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vancomycin + Gentamicin + Rifampin

Explanation:

The patient has MRSA prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE). The appropriate treatment includes Vancomycin + Rifampin and Gentamicin . Rifampin is crucial for targeting bacteria in biofilms which are formed on prosthetic valves.

 

Treatment of Infective Endocarditis Based on Pathogen and Valve Type

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

NVE: Vancomycin or Daptomycin for 6 weeks. (Option B ruled out)

PVE: Vancomycin + Rifampin+ Gentamicin

Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA)

PVE: Nafcillin + Rifampin (both for 6-8 weeks)

+ Gentamicin(for 2 weeks) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is a minor criterion under the Modified Duke’s Criteria for infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Two positive blood cultures with a typical organism

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Presence of a prosthetic valve

 

Explanation:

Positive echocardiographic findings of vegetation (Option A), Two positive blood cultures with a typical organism (Option B), Abscess formation on echocardiogram (Option D): All the given conditions form the major criteria for Infective Endocarditis in Modified Duke’s criteria.

 

Modified Duke’s Criteria - Minor criteria

Predisposing heart condition

Any pre-existing valvular or cardiac abnormality, such as valvular disease, congenital heart defects, or prosthetic valves. (Option C)

Intravenous drug use

Recognised as a significant risk factor for IE.

Fever ≥ 38°C

Commonly seen in patients with IE.

Vascular phenomena

Such as embolic events (stroke, septic pulmonary infarcts), mycotic aneurysms, intracranial haemorrhages and Janeway lesions.

Immunological phenomena

Rheumatoid factor, Osler’s nodes, Roth's spots or glomerulonephritis.

Positive blood culture not meeting major criteria

Isolation of organisms typical of IE in a single culture or other non-major findings.

Suggestive echocardiography

Abnormal findings that raise suspicion but do not meet the criteria for a major criterion. (D529)

questions.text: A 60 y/o man with a mechanical aortic valve presents with 2 weeks of fever, fatigue, and shortness of breath. He has a history of a dental procedure done 3 weeks back. Blood cultures are negative. FDG-PET/CT shows abnormal uptake around the valve. Which major criterion from the Modified Duke’s Criteria does this patient meet?

choices.text: Negative blood culture for a typical organism
Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT

 

Explanation:

The FDG-PET/CT scan revealed abnormal uptake around the prosthetic valve, which is considered a major criterion under the Modified Duke’s Criteria. FDG-PET/CT is useful in cases involving prosthetic valves where traditional blood cultures might be negative, helping to detect inflammation around the valve, consistent with endocardial involvement.

 

Modified Duke’s Criteria - Major criteria

Positive blood cultures
  • Identification of a typical organism from two cultures, or persistent positive cultures drawn more than 12 hours apart.
  • Three or more positive cultures that have been taken over at least one hour apart.
  • A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or a phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800.

Evidence of endocardial involvement
  • Positive echocardiographic findings such as vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation.
  • Oscillating intracardiac masses or partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve.
  • Additional diagnostic tools like FDG-PET/CT or EKG-gated cardiac CT angiograms also meet major criteria for prosthetic valve endocarditis. (Added by the European Society of Cardiology)

Option A and D are minor criteria. Option C is immunological and vascular phenomenon seen in IE and is also minor criteria.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman who is known case of rheumatic heart disease and mitral regurgitation presents with complaints of fever for past 2 weeks.Echo showed vegetations on both surfaces of mitral valve.Blood cultures grew staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following would be immunological phenomenon seen in these patient?

choices.text: Splinter hemorrhages in nails and clubbing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:B) Roth spots and Osler nodes 

Explanation:

Immunological phenomenon are ROG: Roth spots on fundus examination, RA factor is positive( suggest chronic immune activation) , Osler nodes ( Pea shaped nodules in tips of fingers and occurs due to immune complex deposition in dermal vessls) and Glomerulonephritis. Option C is for rheumatic fever and Option A is for vascular phenomenon seen in these patients.

questions.text: In the context of infective endocarditis, what role do MSCRAMMs play in the disease process?

choices.text: They enhance the immune response against pathogens during bacteremia.
They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured endothelium.
They are responsible for the formation of emboli that lead to tissue infarction.
They promote the breakdown of vegetation formed in the heart.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured endothelium.

 

Explanation:

MSCRAMMs (microbial surface components recognizing adhesin matrix molecules) are key adhesion factors that enable bacteria to attach to NBTE or damaged endothelium, crucial for the establishment of infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 65 year old male with ischemic cardiomyopathy and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia presents with fever, malaise, and a new heart murmur. He recently underwent a urinary catheterisation for urinary retention. Blood cultures are positive for gram-positive cocci. What is the most likely causative organism of his infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Enterococcus faecalis

Explanation:

Enterococcus faecalis is a gram-positive cocci and is frequently linked to infective endocarditis following genitourinary procedures, such as catheterization.

 

Portals of entry

Oral cavity:

The entry point for viridans streptococci.

Skin:

Common entry point for staphylococci and S.epidermidis.

Upper respiratory tract:

Source for HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, Kingella). (Option D ruled out)

Gastrointestinal tract:

Streptococcus gallolyticus (formerly S. bovis) is associated with colonic polyps and tumours. (Option B ruled out)

Genitourinary tract and GI tract procedures ( catheterization, colonoscopy):

Source for enterococci.

Nosocomial (hospital-acquired) sources:

S. aureus, coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS), and enterococci are often linked to healthcare-associated infective endocarditis. (Option A ruled out)

Prosthetic valve infections (PVE):

Intraoperative contamination or postoperative infection, especially with S. aureus, CoNS, and gram-negative bacilli.

Intravenous drug use:

Primary portal for S. aureus infections, especially in tricuspid valve involvement. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 68 year old farmer with a prosthetic valve presents with fever, night sweats, and fatigue 6 months post-surgery. Blood cultures are negative. He has goats and cows on his farm . Which organism is most likely responsible for his prosthetic valve endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Coxiella Burnetti

 

Explanation:

 

Culture-Negative Infective Endocarditis (IE)

Coxiella burnetii, and Bartonella species are due to exposure to animals.

Common Cause: One-third to one-half of culture-negative cases are due to prior antibiotic exposure.

Fastidious Organisms:

-Streptococci, Granulicatella, and Abiotrophia species.

-HACEK organisms-Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella

questions.text: A 3 year girl with a history of patent ductus arteriosus presents with high grade fever. Her recent echocardiogram shows vegetations along the inner lining of her aorta. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis for this patient based on her symptoms and history?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Infective endarteritis

Explanation:

The key-words are vegetations along the wall of the aorta in case of P.D.Athat point more towards infective endarteritis.

Infective endarteritis is an infection of the inner layer of arteries, often affecting shunts (arteriovenous, arterio-arterial like PDA) or coarctation of the aorta. All other options will have vegetations along heart valves.

questions.text: A 72 year female with a history of mitral valve prolapse presents with a fever and fatigue for last > 2 weeks. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur and petechiae on her extremities. Blood cultures are sent. What is the leading organism associated with this patient's probable condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus viridans.

 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms have persisted for > 2weeks aligning with the gradual onset characteristic of subacute bacterial endocarditis. Additionally, her history of mitral valve prolapse suggests a predisposing condition for the development of endocarditis. Streptococcus viridans is the most common organism associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis. 

 

Acute Bacterial Endocarditis

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis

-Presentation as Fever, fatigue, and malaise within <2 weeks of infection

 

Signs: Changing heart murmur , Janeway lesions (hemorrhagic macules on palms/soles), petechiae, Roth’s spots, splinter haemorrhages

 

Causative organisms: S. aureus

Slow progression compared to Acute endocarditis.

 

Gradual onset presentation over weeks to months (>2 weeks) but can be life-threatening if untreated.

 

Causative organism: Streptococcus viridans (Most common cause)

questions.text: Which of the following lists the valves in order of frequency of involvement in infective endocarditis, from most to least commonly affected?

choices.text: Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Pulmonic valve
Aortic valve > Mitral valve > Pulmonic valve > Tricuspid valve
Tricuspid valve > Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Pulmonic valve
Pulmonic valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Mitral valve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Pulmonic valve

Explanation:

The Rationale is that mitral valve operates at the highest pressure gradient in the heart followed by the aortic valve. On the right side it is tricuspid followed by the pulmonic valve.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding right-sided infective endocarditis (IE)?

choices.text: Right-sided infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with enterococci than left-sided infective endocarditis.
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen in right-sided infective endocarditis
Injecting particles are more likely to reach the right-sided valves compared to the left-sided valves
Right-sided infective endocarditis has a better long-term prognosis compared to left-sided infective endocarditis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Right-sided infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with enterococci than left-sided infective endocarditis.

 

Explanation:

Enterococci are more common in left-sided infective endocarditis than in right-sided IE. Staphylococcus aureus is responsible for IE in IVDU due to poor injection hygiene. Injected particles damage right-sided valves. Bacteremia from skin bacteria (like S. aureus) easily colonizes these valves.

questions.text: A 72 year old woman presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath after the death of her husband. She has no history of heart disease. ECG shows STE of 2 mm in lead I , aVL, V2-V4. Bedside echocardiogram shows left ventricular ballooning and cardiac biomarkers are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B) Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy

Explanation:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken heart syndrome, is characterized by left ventricular dysfunction often triggered by emotional stress. The patient’s recent stressful event, ballooning of the left ventricle, and elevation of cardiac enzymes align perfectly with this diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common echocardiographic finding associated with rheumatic carditis in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B) Mitral regurgitation

Explanation:

The most common valvular lesion seen in Rheumatic carditis in children is mitral regurgitation. The same patient after 18 years of age will have Mitral stenosis ( predominant lesion) with mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 12 year old girl presents with involuntary, jerky movements in her hands and feet, worsening with stress or purposeful tasks and does not interferes with eating. Her mother tells that for 3 months she had developed arthritis that caused her to limp for a week with swelling of knee and ankle joints. Work up shows increased PR interval, What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A) Penicillin prophylaxis

Explanation:

-The patient has Sydenham's chorea, a delayed complication of acute rheumatic fever following untreated streptococcal pharyngitis.

Penicillin prophylaxis is the initial step to prevent further streptococcal infection and recurrent episodes of rheumatic fever, even if no active infection is present.

-The first episode of Sydenham chorea usually occurs 6 to 8 weeks after a strep throat infection. However, it can also happen up to six months after a child has a fever, or the strep throat infection disappears.

Signs seen in Sydenham's chorea

  1. Tongue fasciculations ("Bag of worms"
  2. Motor impersistence, for example, the "Milkmaid sign" (grip strength fluctuates, as if hand milking a cow)
  3. Inability to sustain tongue protrusion (called Jack-in-the-box tongue or Serpentine tongue, as the tongue slides in and out of the mouth)

 

 Treatment for Sydenham’s Chorea:

Moderate to severe chorea

Category

Medications

Purpose

Initial Antibiotic Prophylaxis

Benzathine penicillin G

Prevent the recurrence of rheumatic fever

Additional Treatment

Neuroleptics: Pimozide, haloperidol, risperidone, olanzapine (Option B ruled out)

Control chorea symptoms

Anticonvulsants: Valproate, carbamazepine (Option D ruled out)

Off-label use for symptom management

Immunomodulatory Therapy

Corticosteroids, Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), Plasma exchange (Option C ruled out)

For severe/persistent symptoms

Mild chorea does not need any treatment

questions.text: A 25 year woman presents with a history of exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and episodes of syncope. She recalls experiencing multiple episodes of sore throat as a child, followed by joint pains, for which she received no definitive treatment. On auscultation, there is a diastolic murmur at the apex and a loud S1. An echocardiogram reveals mitral valve orifice < 1.5 cm2 with left atrial enlargement. What is the next most appropriate step in management?

choices.text: ACE Inhibitors and rate control drugs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mitral balloon valvotomy

 

Explanation:

The patient has rheumatic mitral stenosis secondary to untreated rheumatic fever in childhood, leading to significant narrowing of the mitral valve and left atrial enlargement.Mitral balloon valvotomy is the treatment of choice for symptomatic patients with mitral stenosis who do not have significant mitral regurgitation or left atrial thrombus. It is a minimally invasive procedure that can significantly improve valve function and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and occasional palpitations. O/E, she has an irregular pulse, a loud S1, an opening snap, and a low-pitched diastolic rumble at the apex. She recalls a childhood illness with fever and joint pain requiring hospitalization. Which of the following investigations is NOT primarily used in diagnosing her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Blood cultures

 

Explanation:

  • The hallmark auscultatory findings of mitral stenosis is loud S1, opening snap, and diastolic rumble. Echo will tell you about the severity of Mitral stenosis. ECG will inform about cardiac chamber enlargement and PR interval prolongation which is a minor diagnostic criteria.
  • Blood cultures are primarily used in diagnosing infective endocarditis, not for diagnosing RHD itself. They help identify pathogens when infection is suspected, particularly in patients with fever and valvular vegetation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the major criteria for a low-risk population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Polyarthralgia

 

Explanation:

Polyarthralgia is not part of the major criteria; it is a minor criterion for low-risk populations but is a major criterion for high-risk populations.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about Sydenham's chorea?

choices.text: It is an early manifestation of rheumatic fever
It occurs in all patients with rheumatic fever
It is associated with emotional lability
It is a minor diagnostic criteria

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It is associated with emotional lability

 

Explanation:

Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless movements, and significant emotional instability, often presenting as mood swings and obsessive-compulsive traits. It is more common in females. These features highlight its distinctive neurological profile as a complication of rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presents with fever and migratory joint pain. On auscultation, a soft mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the apex. Echocardiography reveals mitral valve inflammation. Which of the following is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C) Carey Coombs murmur

Explanation:

  • Mitral stenosis is seen after 18 years of age in RHD. Second it does not have valvulitis but has commisural fusion. 
  • Characterstic murmur of RHD is Carey Coombs murmur. it is a soft mid-diastolic apical murmur is due to inflammation of the mitral valve leaflets (valvulitis) in acute rheumatic fever (ARF).
  • It is a Flow murmur that occurs due to increased blood flow across thickened leaflets of mitral valve. This is specifically associated with ARF and reflects early mitral valve involvement. 
  • Austin Flint is seen in Severe AR and Graham Steel is seen in PAH causing mild pulmonic regurgitation.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is most commonly associated with Acute Rheumatic fever in the Indian population?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Polyarthritis

 

Explanation:

Polyarthritis is the most common symptom in ARF, seen in 60-75% of cases. In India, polyarthritis remains a prominent early manifestation of ARF. India has a high incidence of rheumatic heart disease, ranging from 13 to 150 cases per 100,000 population annually.

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a recent history of sore throat. Examination reveals a heart murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Laboratory tests show elevated antistreptolysin O titers. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of his condition?

choices.text: Direct invasion of heart valves by Streptococcus bacteria
Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue
Autoimmune destruction of heart valves due to viral infection
Genetic mutations in heart muscle proteins

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue

 

Explanation:

 

RF is an autoimmune process with ASO antibody causing damage to self cardiac tissues. It is an example of type 2 hypersensitivity/ molecular mimicry.

questions.text: A 11 year boy with a history of acute rheumatic fever without carditis presents for follow-up. Based on the AHA guidelines, what is the recommended duration for continuing secondary prophylaxis in this patient?

choices.text: Continue prophylaxis until the age of 25
Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21

 

Explanation:

 

Secondary Prevention in Acute Rheumatic Fever

Duration of Prophylaxis

Determined by the presence and severity of carditis, age, and time since the last ARF episode

No Carditis

5 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

Carditis without Valvular Disease

10 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

Persistent Valvular Disease

10 years or until 40 years of age, whichever is longer.

Lifelong prophylaxis may be needed in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for ICD implantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

 

Explanation:

While Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome can lead to arrhythmias, it is typically amenable to catheter ablation, making ICD implantation unnecessary in the absence of other risk factors.

questions.text: A 13 year old male is brought to ER by his father who noticed agonal breathing at 5 am in morning. He is the only child in family. Urgent ECG is done. What finding is noted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Coved ST elevation.

Explanation:

Notice the Coved ST elevation in V1-V3 which is seen in Brugada syndrome.  It is a SCN5A defect and causes sudden nocturnal death in South east asian males. 

 

Epsilon waves are seen in ARVD and Deep Q waves in Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and MI. 

 

Extra mile 
Saddleback ST elevation ( check out the arrow drawn at lead V2 )  is seen in Type 2 Brugada syndrome

questions.text: A 15 year old male presents to the ED after experiencing a brief episode of syncope. He reports occasional palpitations and dizziness. His family history is significant for sudden cardiac death at a young age. An ECG of leads V1-V3 is given below. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient, given the findings?

choices.text: Prescribe a beta-blocker and advise lifestyle modifications
It is also called Broken heart syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Deploy an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

 

Explanation:

  • ECG shows Coved ST elevations greater than 2 mm in the right precordial leads (V1-V3).
  • In lieu of SCD in family , ICD should be deployed as early as possible

questions.text: A 68 year old postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department with chest pain and dyspnea after a recent stressful event. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation and cardiac biomarkers are elevated. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Perform coronary angiography

 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms, ST-segment elevation on ECG, and troponin elevation suggest Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, especially given her postmenopausal status and recent stress. The initial management focuses on ruling out obstructive coronary disease through coronary angiography while addressing acute symptoms.
